Name: Issue Detector Processor (Cosmos2SCILAB + INP-SCILAB + SCILAB2Orion **)

Documentation.Description:
Basic Concepts

Cosmos2Scilab is a Java Timer service that provides SCILAB module weather forecast and load profile data in two different .csv files. Every fifteen minutes it retrieves weather forecast and load profile data by two REST services and then writes/updates the values into two files that have a specific format acknowledged by the SCILAB module. Weather.csv file contains a list of weather attributes such as values of temperature, cloud cover and wind speed related to both the current weather condition and the situation in the next 1 to 24 hours. Loadprofile.csv file contains the load attributes for each monitored meter installed at Terni trial site. Both files are essential for SCILAB module to perform its analysis.
This component can be eventually re-used and customized to fulfill the general need of having a piece of software which writes data onto .csv files.

The INP-SCILAB module is a scilab code which main inputs are produced by Cosmos2Scilab module and its main outputs are two .csv files that are read by Silab2Orion module. INP-SCILAB module has two main tasks: 1/ Read the load profile data file, which contains the measures acquired by smart meters. The module verifies the measurements, completes unknown data and runs an unbalanced load flow in order to compute load losses at power-lines and voltage drops. 2/ Read the weather forecast and using the LibSVM toolbox for scilab, performs a short-term prediction of consumed and produced power by all customers. Finally, the INP-SCILAB writes two .csv files: a first one including voltage drops values for current state of the network and the predicted values. The second file includes the predicted power consumption and generation by every customer.

Scilab2Orion is a Java Timer service which reads data from two .csv file produced by Scilab and then writes/updates as many ORION Context Broker GE entities as the rows of these .csv files. The attributes of the first entity (entityName = "PowLosVotDrop" ) contains values of Power Losses/Voltage Drops for each Line of the trial grid. The attributes of the second one (entityName = "LoadPrediction" ) contains values of DownstreamActivePower, Upstream_ActivePower and ReactivePower prediction for the next 1, 3, 6, 12 and 24 hours.
This component can be eventually re-used and customized to fulfill the general need of having a REST service which is connected to the ORION GE.

Basic Design Principles

Figure 1 shows the Cosmos2Scilab domain model. It consists of a Timer class “Cosmos2ScilabTimer” that schedules a TimerTask class “Cosmos2Scilab” and two classes “WeatherForecast” and “Load” (java bean) that respectively represent the attributes of a weather forecast and the Load profile.


Figure 1: Cosmos2Scilab domain model

Figure 2 shows the Scilab domain model. It consists of four blocks. ‘simulator_INP.sce’ is the main function that reads the input files every 15 minutes, organize the data and calls the ‘loadFlow_INP.sce’ and ‘predictor_INP.sce’ functions. ‘loadFlow_INP.sce’ runs an unbalanced load flow and computes the load losses and voltage drops on every line. ‘predictor_INP’ runs every hour and predicts the consumption/production of every installed meter using the libSVM library and a matrix of pre-defined parameters. ‘customerData.sce’ includes the physical parameters of the trial grid, including bus-bars, power lines characteristics, customers IDs and power-base values.


Figure 2: INP-Scilab domain model

Figure 3 shows the Scilab2Orion domain model. It consists of a Timer class “Scilab2OrionTimer” that schedules a TimerTask class “Scilab2Orion” and two classes “PredictionContextElement” and “PowerVoltaveContextElement” (ContextElement) that respectively represent the attributes of a Prediction and a measure of PowerLosses and VoltageDrops.


Figure 3: Scilab2Orion domain model
Documentation.Preface:
Within this document you find a self-contained open specification of the aforementioned Domain Specific Enabler (DSE).

Please consult the appropriate pages on the FINESCE website in order to understand the complete context of the related FINESCE trials and this DSE.

Usage:
COSMOS2SCILAB (Java TIMER client)

Download the artefact (in the form a .jar file) from the download section.
Open the .jar file (you can use an appropriate software like “winRar” or "7zip"); open the “cosmos2scilab.properties”s file located in the root directory and then amend the following configuration properties: 

cosmos2scilab.wheterCsvFile = (path to write weather file)
cosmos2scilab.loadCsvFile = (path to write load file)

Install a java JDK (e.g. 1.6 / 1.7). The cosmos2scilab module contains a java timer class that has to be launched from the command line by using the following: 

java -jar cosmos2scilab-0.0.1-SNAPSHOT.jar

It retrieves weather data and load data from a REST service, parses the data and writes them into two new files (weatherData.csv, loadData.csv).

In order to verify that the deploy of the cosmos2scilab application has been done successfully and that it consequently runs, you have to check that the files are being written in the above mentioned paths.

INP SCILAB

All functions are developed in Scilab 5.5.1, Scilab is free and open source software for numerical computation providing a powerful computing environment for engineering and scientific applications. Scilab is available for download free of charge under Mac OSx, Windows and GNU/Linux.

It is necessary to install Scilab in order to run the codes ('.sce' files) that are part of the INP-SCILAB block. Scilab binaries can be downloaded directly from the Scilab homepage

www.scilab.org

or from the Download area

download

It is strongly recommended to follow the installing recommendations published by Scilab Consortium

introscilab.pdf

After download and install Scilab, open the folder containing Scilab-5.5.1 and launch from the command line in Linux by using the following: 

./bin/scilab -nw

If you are using Windows or MacOSx, you can double-click on the Scilab-5.5.1 icon.

It is mandatory to install a library that includes SVM tools and large-scale linear classification in order to use the INP-SCILAB module. The toolbox is called “libsvm and liblinear 1.4.1.1-1”, to install it write on Scilab environment: 

--> atomsInstall('libsvm')

Once installed, restart Scilab application and you are ready to compile the .sce codes.

For more information about SVM library, please, refer to:

libsvm

INP-SCILAB module is composed of five codes .sce:
  1. 'simulator_INP.sce' - Simulator manager and time processing
  2. 'customerData.sce' - This file contains the system data
  3. 'launch_INPSCILAB.sce' - Main file to launch the INP-SCILAB module
  4. 'loadFlow_INP.sce' - Unbalanced Load Flow
  5. 'predictor_INP.sce' - SVM predictor
As well, it uses several '.csv' files for prediction support:
  1. 'history_INP.csv' - Hourly historical consumptions/generation of users
  2. 'onlineHistory.csv' - File that is created by the module itself to store last 1-month data
  3. 'loadData_Profil.csv' - Quarterly historical consumtion/generation of users

A sample of 'history_INP.csv' and 'loadData_Profile.csv' files are shared.

And a '.sce' file that contains the filepaths:

  1. 'simulator_properties.sce'

Please, before launching the simulator, modify this file in order to select the read/write paths. 

simulator_filepath=(path to read SCILAB-INP codes)
input_filepath=(path to read load file)
output_filepath=(path to write results files)

'simulator_INP.sce’

'simulator_INP' is the main function of the module. It controls the load flow and predictor algorithm, manipulates data and reads/writes .csv files.

‘customerData.sce’

'customerData.sce' contains the main information about the topology of the trial grid. Update this file with the characteristics of your grid. The main variables to set are:


Table 1: Trial Grid topology characteristics


Table 2: Line Data Format (d)


Table 3: PQ Load Data Format (po)


Table 4: Customer codes Data Format (codes)

‘predictor_INP.sce’

'predictor_INP.sce' contains the algorithm for short-term prediction based on Support Vector Machines method. It is important to update the SVM parameters according to your data sets on the parameters_svm matrix. In order to identify the correct parameters you can use the WEKA open-source software or you can use other software to perform a grid search algorithm. For more information about WEKA and forecasting models, please refer to:

Time+Series+Analysis+and+Forecasting+with+Weka

The example case uses the epsilon_SVR regression type and the Radial Basis Function (RBF) for the Kernel Function. For that reason the parameters c (cost), g (gamma) and p (epsilon) are used. However, each data set has a different set of parameters. Therefore, you have to validate your data sets and parameters by training your model and applying a convenient accuracy measure. ‘predictor_INP.sce’ includes three accuracy measures: Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE), Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) and Mean Absolute Error (MAE).

As well, the example case uses 1h time-stamped historic data sets to train and update every hour the predictor model. These data sets have to be included in the input file 'history_INP.csv' and are read by the 'predictor_INP.sce'. 'history_INP.csv' have the following format:


Table 5: 'history_INP.csv' Data Format

‘loadFlow_INP.sce’

‘loadFlow_INP.sce’ contains the algorithm to compute the load losses and voltage drops. The algorithm is based on the papers:

“A Direct approach for distribution system load flow solutions,” Jen-Hao Teng, IEEE Transactions on Power Delivery, vol. 18, no. 3, July 2003.

“Power Flow in four-wire distribution networks – General Approach,” Rade Ciric, Antonio Padilha and Luis Ochoa, IEEE Transactions on Power Systems, vol. 18, no. 4, November 2003.

Please, be aware that input data is in [p.u.] units and output data is in [V], [A] and [W] units.

‘launch_INPSCILAB.sce’

'launch_INPSCILAB.sce' launches automatically the INP-SCILAB module. After the first simulation is done, verify that the OUTPUT folder has two files: 'prediction.csv' and 'powerLosses_VoltageDrops.csv'.
In order to launch the simulation write on Scilab the following: 

-->exec('launch_INPSCILAB.sce',-1)
-->launch_INPSCILAB()

If you have an error message with: 

File "launch_INPSCILAB.sce" does not exist.

Verify that you have set correctly the path way directory. You can get current Scilab directory writing the following: 

-->pwd

If you want to modify the current directory write: 

-->chdir('_mydirectoryname_')

SCILAB2ORION (Java TIMER client)

IMPORTANT: we kindly remind you that this software module is strictly tight to the use of ORION Context Broker GE thus meaning that you should have previously set up an ORION instance of yours. Please have a look at ORION GE documentation at the following link publishsubscribe-context-broker-orion-context-broker

Download the artefact (in the form a .jar file) from the bottom of the page.
Open the .jar file (you can use an appropriate software like “winRar” or "7zip"); open the “scilab2orion.properties” file located in the root directory and then amend the following configuration properties: 

scilab2orion.orionServerUrl = http://(your ORION instance URL):1026
scilab2orion.registerContexPath = NGSI10/updateContext

scilab2orion.fileInputPowerVoltage = (your file path)//powerLosses_VoltageDrops.csv
scilab2orion.fileInputPredictions  = (your file path)/predictions.csv

Save the changes to the .properties file and deploy the .jar file on a server with a jre installed. We recommend you to use an updated version of Java JRE (e.g. 1.6 / 1.7); we have used a JDK 1.6.xx. The scilab2orion module contains a java timer class that has to be launched from the command line by using the following: 

java -jar scilab2orion-0.0.1-SNAPSHOT.jar

To verify that the deploy of the scilab2orion application has been done successfully and that it consequently runs, you have to access ORION to verify that new “PowLosAndVoltDrops” entities have been saved; in particular one entity for each line of the following type should be created (or updated in case it already exists) in the NoSQL DB underlying ORION (i.e. MongoDB):

Overview:
What you get

Issue Detector Processor consists of:
  • COSMOS2SCILAB - a Java TIMER client which, every fifteen minutes, writes the last weather forecast and the last load profile information retrieved from Cosmos onto two .csv files.
  • INP SCILAB – a SCILAB-based Algorithm which, every fifteen minutes, reads two .csv files created by COSMOS2SCILAB, ii) computes the power losses and voltage drops in the trial grid, iii) performs short-term prediction of the consumption/production power, uses this forecasting to compute future power losses and voltage drops, and iv) finally writes the results on output files.
  1. (from loadData.csv) - Last load profile information
  2. (from weatherData.csv) - Last weather forecast
  3. (to powerLosses_VoltageDrops.csv) - PowerLosses/VoltageDrops data for each Line of the trial grid,
  4. (to predictions.cvs) - Load Prediction data for each Meter of the trial grid.
  • SCILAB2ORION - a Java TIMER client which, every fifteen minutes, reads:
  1. (from powerLosses_VoltageDrops.csv) - PowerLosses/VoltageDrops data for each Line of the trial grid,
  2. (from predictions.cvs) - Load Prediction data for each Meter of the trial grid,
    and then writes/updates as many ORION Context Broker GE entities as the rows in each .csv file.

Why to get it

A reference implementation of a TIMER client which retrieves weather forecast and load profile information from COSMOS and writes it onto two .csv files.
A reference implementation of an algorithm coded in SCILAB which calculates load prediction based on information about weather conditions and load profile.
A reference implementation of a TIMER client which reads two files (output of SCILAB processing) and then writes their values to ORION GE entities.

Target Usage

  • Energy companies that would need information on load prediction in a specific area of the grid.
  • Third-party applications (such as those developed by SMEs involved in Phase3)
